articles.headline: U.S. Push to Expand in Pakistan Meets Resistance
articles.snippet: Efforts to increase aid, as well as the footprint of the U.S. Embassy and security contractors, are aggravating tensions.
articles.abstract: Efforts to increase aid, as well as the footprint of the U.S. Embassy and security contractors, are aggravating tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Steps by the United States to vastly expand its aid to Pakistan, as well as the footprint of its embassy and private security contractors here, are aggravating an already volatile anti-American mood as Washington pushes for greater action by the government against the Taliban.

articles.headline: Airlines Seek Global Allies to Expand
articles.snippet: The story of troubled Japan Airlines — currently courted by several would-be partners — is an example of the airlines’ attempt to grow again, by creating partnerships.
articles.abstract: The story of troubled Japan Airlines — currently courted by several would-be partners — is an example of the airlines’ attempt to grow again, by creating partnerships.

articles.headline: Health Insurance Exchanges: Will They Work?
articles.snippet: Critics worry that big insurers may shun the exchanges or that consumers will not be able to afford what is offered.
articles.abstract: Critics worry that big insurers may shun the exchanges or that consumers will not be able to afford what is offered.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the sleeper issue in the current health care debate.

articles.headline: In a Guinea Seized by Violence, Women Are Prey
articles.snippet: Pictures showing sexual attacks on women by soldiers suppressing a demonstration appear to have hardened the opposition’s determination.
articles.abstract: Pictures showing sexual attacks on women by soldiers suppressing a demonstration appear to have hardened the opposition’s determination.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONAKRY, Guinea  Cellphone snapshots, ugly and hard to refute, are circulating here and feeding rage: they show that women were the particular targets of the Guinean soldiers who suppressed a political demonstration at a stadium here last week, with victims and witnesses describing rapes, beatings and acts of intentional humiliation.

articles.headline: Obama Aides Act to Fix Safety Net
articles.snippet: Officials said that a new effort would not add up to a second stimulus package, only an extension of the first.
articles.abstract: Officials said that a new effort would not add up to a second stimulus package, only an extension of the first.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With unemployment expected to rise well into next year even as the economy slowly recovers, the Obama administration and Democratic leaders in Congress are discussing extending several safety net programs as well as proposing new tax incentives for businesses to renew hiring.

articles.headline: Prepaid, but Not Prepared for Debit Card Fees
articles.snippet: Prepaid debit cards are among the consumer banking industry’s fastest-growing products, but often their convenience comes with hidden fees.
articles.abstract: Prepaid debit cards are among the consumer banking industry’s fastest-growing products, but often their convenience comes with hidden fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buying a prepaid debit card these days is just about as easy as picking up a bottle of shampoo or a candy bar. Walk into a Wal-Mart or almost any major drugstore, and rows of plastic worth $25, $100 and even $500 beckon from kiosks alongside prepaid phone cards and gift cards for retailers.

articles.headline: Investment Indigestion at Stanford
articles.snippet: The university appears to be rethinking an investment strategy that relies on big bets on illiquid assets like real estate.
articles.abstract: The university appears to be rethinking an investment strategy that relies on big bets on illiquid assets like real estate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stanford University is holding a garage sale.

articles.headline: Condé Nast Closes Gourmet and 3 Other Magazines
articles.snippet: The 68-year-old magazine, aimed at the luxury market and run by Ruth Reichl, will close, as will Cookie, Elegant Bride and Modern Bride.
articles.abstract: The 68-year-old magazine, aimed at the luxury market and run by Ruth Reichl, will close, as will Cookie, Elegant Bride and Modern Bride.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s Rachael Ray’s world now  we’re all just cooking in it.

articles.headline: Letterman Apologizes on the Air to His Wife
articles.snippet: Mr. Letterman’s remarks were his first public comments since Thursday when he revealed details of an apparent extortion attempt.
articles.abstract: Mr. Letterman’s remarks were his first public comments since Thursday when he revealed details of an apparent extortion attempt.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Letterman apologized on the air Monday to his wife, Regina, for his revelation last week of his sexual relationships with staff members, saying she had been “horribly hurt” and adding, “I’ve got my work cut out for me” to mend the relationship.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Adding Health Advice to Online Medical Records
articles.snippet: A Web start-up led by a former Google executive plans to generate personalized health plans.
articles.abstract: A Web start-up led by a former Google executive plans to generate personalized health plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The national health care debate right now is all about giving more people affordable access to doctors and hospitals. Yet the vast majority of health care decisions  80 percent or more, experts say  are really made by individuals, instead of medical professionals, whether choices are about diet and exercise or ways of managing chronic conditions like diabetes and heart disease.

articles.headline: Stocks and Gold Gain as Investors Shun the Dollar
articles.snippet: Shares rose ahead of the start of earnings season, and the value of the dollar skidded as investors fretted over a report that crude oil could one day be priced in other currencies.
articles.abstract: Shares rose ahead of the start of earnings season, and the value of the dollar skidded as investors fretted over a report that crude oil could one day be priced in other currencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors clamored to buy pretty much anything on Tuesday  as long as it was not the dollar.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Keith Bradsher
